title-group.article-title: TRUST, PRUDENCE AND HISTORY: JOHN DUNN AND THE TASKS OF POLITICAL THEORY

The revival of substantive political theory in what is usually called an 'Anglo-American' mode, is widely held to have been sent into overdrive by the publication of John Rawls' Λ Theory of Justice (Oxford, 1972) and the launching of the journal Philosophy and Public Affairs in 1971. As Barry remarks in 'The Strange Death of Political Philosophy', the rebirth of analytical political theory also benefited from much work in political economy and economics, especially that in game theory and other forms of formal theory. Recent representative selections of analytical political theory in this vein would include: Alan Hamlin and Philip Pettit, The Good Polity: Normative Analysis of the State (Oxford, 1989); John Broome, Weighing Goods (Oxford, 1992); Will Kymlicka, Liberalism, Community and Culture (Oxford, 1991); and Brian Barry, Theories of Justice (Vol. 1 of A Treatise of Social Justice) (Hemel Hempstead, 1989).

Consider, for example, the work in the United States of scholars like Leo Strauss, Reinhold Niebuhr and Hannah Arendt. In France of Raymond Aron, Alexandre Kojeve, Louis Althusser and Paul Ricoeur. In Germany, of Adomo and Horkheimer, Habermas and Gadamer. In Italy of Norberto Bobbio and in the UK of Michael Oakeshott, John Plamenatz and Isaiah Berlin. It is fair to say, of course, that much of this work was done in the history of ideas, a point recognized by the likes of Barry and Miller. Their point is precisely that it was non-historical substantive political theory that was 'dead'. It is also true to say that 'political theory' as it is usually practised in the Anglo-American worlds is slightly different from cognate activities on mainland Europe. However, most of the above men- tioned writers (and indeed many others) were certainly not exclusively concerned with the history of ideas or had a conception of political philosophy that saw the history of ideas as a crucial component of any substantive theory. This was certainly the view of, for example, Strauss, Gadamer and Oakeshott, though naturally in different ways. This might be incorrect; it does not, however, suggest that political philosophy was 'dead'.

I shall refer throughout this paper to the kind of political theory that has, allegedly, been 'reborn' as 'Anglo-American' political theory, a common enough terminology these days. I should emphasize, however, that this term should be taken to refer to a way of doing political theory and the assumptions associated with it, rather than having any specific geographical referent. Thus (and for example), Phillipe Van Parijs, who teaches in Bel- gium, does on my account 'Anglo-American political theory' whereas William Connolly, who teaches in America, does not.

This is not the place to go over the many and variegated turns of the realist vs. anti-realist argument in twentieth-century philosophy. Suffice to say that as opposed to the realist view which sees fixed, determinate existing objects for social investigations, anti-realism sug- gests that there are only particular interpretations or assumptions embedded in still further assumptions, and so on. The assumptions of anti-realist arguments are clearly compatible with the emphasis on context of Dunn and others of the Cambridge school. There are, of course, a wide number of possible anti-realist views (as there are realist views) and one should not assume that Dunn would subscribe to them all.
See, for example, Skinner's views as developed in the essays gathered together by James Tully in Meaning and Context.

Here I do not mean to imply anything other than the fact that Dunn's usage of 'prudence' is very different from the general sense these theorists would give to the term 'rational', with the instru- mental sense of which it might be confused.

I am, I know, sidestepping the complex and important question of whether all so-called postmodern readings of politics actually do this. I accept that some are much better disposed to Dunn's sort of history than others. In the article on postmodem political theory cited earlier (Rengger, 'No Time Like The Present?'), and in the book from which both that article and this are drawn, I drew a distinction between 'hard' sceptical postmodems such as Jean Baudrillard and soft sceptical postmodems such as William Connolly. In the present context the latter would be more likely to be sympathetic to Dunn's argument than the former.

I should emphasize that I do not suggest the state is about to disappear, nor am I subscribing to any fashionable posthistoire fantasies. I merely assert that the institutions and processes that we call — in convenient shorthand — the state can hardly expect to remain unchanged by the rapidity and power of the general pace of global change.

The four most frequently cited communitarians, of course. See Charles Taylor, Sources of The Se//(Cambridge, Mass., 1989); Michael Sandel, Liberalism and the Limits of Justice (Cambridge, 1983); Michael Walzer, Spheres of Justice (New York, 1983); Alisdair Maclntyre, After Virtue (London, 1981). It is worth pointing out, I think, that linking these four in this way does grave damage to all of the thinkers concerned. Of the four just mentioned only two, Walzer and Sandel, seem unworried by the use of the label 'commu- nitarian' (which is more usually and — in some senses appropriately — applied to writers such as Amitai Etzioni). Maclntyre has expressly repudiated the idea that he is a commu- nitarian (see his 'Reply to my Critics', in After Maclntyre, ed. Nancy Rosenblum (Cambridge, Mass., 1989)). I discuss this problem in more detail in Political Theory, Modernity and Postmodemity, especially in the introduc- tion and Ch. 4.

See Quentin Skinner, On Justice, The Common Good and Liberty', in Dimensions of Radical Democracy: Pluralism, Citizenship, Community, ed. Chantai Mouffe (London, 1992). Skinner and Pocock have been especially influential of course in bringing the republican tradition into greater focus over the last few years. Given the complicated history of the relations between liberal and republican thought that they so well document, it is nicely ironic that they seek to attack versions of modern liberalism with weapons taken from a tradition so deeply, if ambiguously, implicated in its development. It is also worth pointing out here, however, that 'republicanism' as such has also been 'revived' (if that is quite the word) by some scholars who hardy share either the methodological or the normative agenda's of the Cambridge school, to wit some of the friends and allies of Leo Strauss, especially Harvey Mansfield and Thomas Pangle (see, for example, Mansfield's Taming the Prince: The Ambivalence of Modern Executive Power (Baltimore, 1989) and Pangle's The Spirit of Modern Republicanism (Chicago, 1988)). I do not propose to argue the toss between the Cambridge school and Straussian versions of 'republicanism' here, I merely point out that this is contested ground.

It is also common to writers connected to the Cambridge school. Richard Tuck, for example, in his recent and excellent Philosophy and Government 1572-1651 (Cambridge, 1993), provides a slightly different but nonetheless related account of the rise of a particular set of political assumptions that created at least some aspects of the origins of contemporary liberalism. Again, however, it is worth noting the similarity (in form, not content) of what we might call the 'Straussian republicans' Mansfield and Pangle'. Mansfield begins his account of the rise of the modern executive with Machiavelli, and in doing so explicitly feels the need to distance his interpretation from that of Skinner and Pocock (see Mansfield, Taming the Prince, pp. xxiii-xxiv), and the subtitle of Pangle's book is 'The Moral Vision of the American Founders and the Philosophy of Locke'. As with Dunn and Skinner it is with interpretations of Machiavelli and Locke that the critique of existing liberalism begins.

The search for better, not wholly instrumental, readings of reason has recently become more popular, even among analytical theorists, for example Jon Elster. See, amongst many other works, Jon Elster, The Cement of Society (Cambridge, 1984). Onora O'Neill is perhaps the philosopher who has done most to explore these issues. See O. O'Neill, Constructions of Reason: Explorations in Kantian Practical Philosophy (Cambridge, 1989).

Much the same is true of those 'Utopian realists' who, I suggested earlier, in this respect at least make common cause with Dunn. Giddens, for example, insists that we must 'balance Utopian ideals with realism' given the extremely high-consequence risks of contemporary social life, echoing Dunn's insistence on the complexity and risk inherent in modernity, and Booth stresses that his utopianism is not an end-point Utopia but a process Utopia, agreeing with Dunn's concern that the third task of political theory is to conceive of realistic ways of getting from where we are to where we might, and should, aim to be.

There are, of course, discussions of this sort in a variety of modern moral and political theories. For example Onora O'Neill has given accounts of this issue from a strongly Kantian perspective, and the notion of reasonableness and what it leads to plays a central role in John Finnis's influential rearticulation of Natural Law theory. See Onora O'Neill, 'Vindicating Reason', in The Cambridge Companion to Kant, ed. Paul Guyer (Cambridge, 1992); and John Finnis, Natural Law and Natural Rights (Oxford, 1980). The beginnings of my own approach to this question can be found in Political Theory, Modernity and Postmodernity, Chs. 3 and 4.
